I use the first option.  It doesn't remove your ability to test protected
methods if you put the tests in the same package and set your classpath
appropriately.

main
  |
  + com
     |
     + myApp
test
  |
  + com
     |
     + myApp

I've used a 4th option, which is to put the test classes in the same
directory as the main source, and use a naming convention of
TestMyClass.java and TestSomeGroupFixture.java.  Then I use ant to build to
two separate directory trees, (similar to above, with build the parent to
test and main).  Pretty similar to option 1, but perhaps slightly easier to
remember to move your test classes.  

Of course, if you run all your tests after building your jar (or compiling),
then you'll immediately see your omission. :)

There was a quite involved discussion of testing private methods on this
list recently and it looked like there was a variety of solutions.

From: Steven Webster [mailto:steven.webster@...]
Sent: Thursday, June 07, 2001 11:12 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?


I've inherited a huge codebase which I'll be taking over development for; as
soon as
possible, I want to put skeletal JUnit tests in place for every class; as I
perform
refactorings, and as I introduce new functionality, my intention is to first
flesh out
JUnit tests, before adding feature/refactoring.
 
This raises several questions, most of all related to what are the best
practices
for keeping Unit Tests alongside code.
 
Options as I see them:
 
1.    A separate directory tree with a root note of test, the package
structure of
      which reflects that of the codebase; keep the tests completely
isolated from
      production code, the downside being that if I refactor code around
packages,
      I have to remember to move tests as well; also, removes my ability to
test
      private and protected methods..
 
2.    A 'test' directory in each package of the codebase, containing
TestXXXX
      classes; with a TestXXXX class for each XXXX class in the package
above.
      Again, can't test public/protected methods, and a little extra work is

      required to remove tests from production code, but not that much.
 
3.    Actually make each class in the production code it's own test, ie put
the
      JUnit testing code in the class itself.  This gives me access to
protected
      and private methods, AND makes it easy to refactor and move tests
around.
      Another upside is that the JUnit plugin for Together UML will create
all
      these test skeletons for me in this manner.  Downside (and I see it as
a 
      pretty big downside) is that my JUnit tests are all but impossible to
remove
      from my production code.
 
Has anyone got any thoughts on this problem ?    Anyone been in a similar
situation, and got suggestions they could offer ?
 
Cheers,
 
Steven
